name: 1-day Cotton Spinning on the Wheel Workshop
description:
Next Workshop Date: May 24th, 2014

For Intermediate to Advanced Spinners

Learn the unique method of spinning cotton in this fun and relaxed one-day workshop. 

Enjoy an intimate class setting in the Vegan Yarn studio; our home in Sapperton, New Westminster. Learn about the history and botany of naturally pigmented cottons, and bring home your very own skein of hand spun organic and fair-trade cotton, and plenty more to practice with.

Time: 10am-5pm, Saturday May 24th, 2014

Bring: 
Your spinning wheel
lazy kate
niddy noddy
any other spinning accessories you normally use
lunch (optional, see below)
pen or pencil and paper if you would like to take notes

You will receive:
A selection of cottons for spinning
A folder to organize your samples with notes, and additional information

Lunch options:
We will break for lunch at noon for about 45 minutes or so.

You may bring your lunch or,

Get takeout from any of the restaurants in the neighbourhood (Sushi, Thai, Chinese, Italian) They are all about 5 minutes or less to walk to or,

For $5 to cover the cost of ingredients you can enjoy a homemade all-organic, vegan, gluten-free and soy free lunch that I'll prepare.


Coffee, Tea, and Snacks will be provided through the day.

name: Organic & Fair Trade Spinning Cotton Fifo
description:
50g/1.76oz

Difficulty: Advanced

Fifo is a rare, deep mauve. This spinning fibre is both Organic and Fair Trade, it comes from Peru. Organic cotton is gorgeous to spin with, just make sure you have your wheel set up to spin at a fairly fast pace, and use a long-draw method (I use assisted long-draw). I have been spinning almost exclusively with organic cotton for the past few years, except for the occasional dip into bamboo, soysilk, ingeo, linen etc., and I love it more and more. This may be too challenging to a new spinner, in which case you may want to try some of the other fibres available here. but don't worry, cotton is not as hard to spin as you might think, just take your time, and enjoy.

After spinning cotton, you can boil it in plain, untreated water to set the twist. With naturally pigmented cottons like this one, the colour will slightly deepen the longer you boil it. (5 minutes to 2 hours). The colour also gently 'cures' over time and sets in to an even deeper, richer tone.

name: Deep Green - Pakucho Worsted
description:
Worsted Weight 
80m/88yds 
50g / 1.76 oz 
10/2/5

EKO Certified Organic by Control Union/SKAL & Certified FairTrade

Pakucho cottons are incredibly soft and light, easy to knit, and are a great choice for babies, children, and those with sensitivities. 
Pakucho Original Worsted is also perfectly compatible with Vegan Yarn Nature Dyed Arcturus Series.

"Grown on small farmyard plots by rural artisan and Indian families, native cotton cultivation supports self-help development programs for the benefit of peasant communities and urban women's migrant co-operatives. In the High Jungle of Peru, native cotton has already replaced several thousand hectares of clandestinely cultivated coca leaf from which the fatally addicting cocaine paste is synthesized. Today, hundreds of Indian peasant farmers benefit from the revival of native and organically grown cotton." -Peru Naturtex/Pakucho

name: Beach Cowl
description: Easy enough to memorize after a few repeats, and perfect for summertime knitting. Beach Cowl is a lot like that summer novel; its fun, easy and satisfying. You will need one skein of Sirius Bulky yarn, a 5mm/US8 circular needle, and a darning needle for weaving in ends. By purchasing this pattern you will get a paper pattern in the mail. If you would like to download a PDF of this pattern, it is available on ravelry here.

name: Deneb Shawl
description: Deneb is a fine, luxe shawl that is knitted using random knit and purl rows. A randomization pattern is written for those who would rather follow the same pattern I used. This pattern gives knitters who love lace weight an opportunity to knit without actually knitting in a lace pattern, and ‘just knit’. Great for when you just want to make something gorgeous without having to think too hard about what you’re doing. Measures 25” down the centre and 76” across the top, end to end after blocking. Requires: one skein of Deneb by Vegan Yarn 100g or two balls of River Spirit Lace by Quo Vadis or two balls of Pakucho Original Lace a 2.5mm/US 1 1/2 circular needle a row counter (optional) and a darning needle for weaving in ends If you would like to make one like the shawl pictured in the second and fourth photos, you can use an assortment of the Pakucho Laceweight naturally pigmented yarns, or hand spin the Pakucho sliver. The shawl shown was made with an assortment of handspun Pakucho sliver. By purchasing this pattern you will get a paper pattern in the mail. If you would like to download a PDF of this pattern, it is available on ravelry here.

Indigo has a rich history, and has been used all over the world to create striking blue shades. Indigo is the only natural dye that makes blue. If you are unfamiliar with indigo, you probably wear it on a regular basis, since it is used to dye blue jeans. However, nowadays denim is typically dyed using a synthetic form of indigo. This yarn was dyed using natural indigo. The colour varies gently through the skein so your project will have a nice hand-dyed look to it. The process of dyeing naturally takes time, indigo dyeing is a unique and interesting process. First a reduction is carefully made (a concentrate), and the yarn is prepared by scouring, and then a number of steps have to be made before the yarn is introduced to the dyebath including adjustment of the ph. The neat part is, that when the yarn is in the dye, it is a clear yellowish colour, and only after it is removed and exposed to air does it turn blue! Repeated dipping allows for deeper shades.

This yarn is EKO Certified Organic by Control Union/SKAL & Certified FairTrade, it comes from Peru Naturtex, and it is hand dyed in small batches at the Vegan Yarn studio in New Westminster, BC, Canada.

name: Beach Glass - Hemp
description:
112g/4oz 
Difficulty: Easy

Like flax, hemp is a bast fibre and has a very long staple length, and has a coarse and earthy feel. Once your project is complete, wash it a few times to enjoy its gorgeous softness and drape. No need to worry about pilling or shrinking, hemp doesn't do that! Hemp is also incredibly eco-friendly since it is so hardy it can grow in nearly any soil, so it can be used for reclaiming areas that have become eroded or otherwise abused by industrial farming. Like bamboo, it naturally repels insects so it never needs to be sprayed. 
The more you wear it, and wash it, the lovelier it becomes.

name: Organic & Fair Trade Spinning Cotton - Moka
description:
'Moka' is lusciously soft, and lofty. This spinning fibre is both Organic and Fair Trade, it comes from Peru. Organic cotton is gorgeous to spin with, just make sure you have your wheel set up to spin at a fairly fast pace, and use a long-draw method (I use assisted long-draw). I have been spinning almost exclusively with organic cotton for the past few years, except for the occasional dip into bamboo, soysilk, ingeo, linen etc., and I love it more and more. This may be too challenging to a new spinner, in which case you may want to try some of the other fibres available here. but don't worry, cotton is not as hard to spin as you might think, just take your time, and enjoy.

After spinning cotton, you can boil it in plain, untreated water to set the twist. With naturally pigmented cottons like this one, the colour will slightly deepen the longer you boil it. (5 minutes to 2 hours). The colour also gently 'cures' over time and sets in to an even deeper, richer tone. Add a spoonful of baking soda or soda ash to the water to bring out the deepest shade.

name: Water Retted Flax Top
description:
112 g/4 oz
Difficulty: Easy

Natural, undyed and unbleached flax, also known in fibre form as linen, this fibre is super easy to spin, with a staple length at least 4 inches long.  This is the perfect fibre for beginners as its very forgiving. Linen has the advantage of ageing well, the more you wear and wash it, the softer it gets. Dew Retted Flax is coarse, and has a particularly horsey/barn smell. After spinning, you may prefer to wash it several times before knitting since you can soften it up considerably that way, which makes it much less coarse, and improves the softness.

name: Black Diamond - Bamboo
description:
Bamboo

112 g/4 oz
Difficulty: Easy

Carbonized Bamboo, also known as Black Diamond, comes ready to spin. Black Diamond is quite easy to spin as it has crimp to it, making it fairly wool-like, and has a very long staple (fibre length). It is light and lofty, perfect for garments and other projects that you want to have some memory and body. The colour is a deep slate, nearly black but not quite. Carbonized Bamboo has anti-microbial properties and is a sustainable fibre.

name: Handmade Fair Trade Recycled Glass Stitch Markers
description:
I made these stitch markers using Fair Trade recycled glass beads. 
The set includes one larger bead marker to use in projects that require a centre or end of round marker. There are five pieces total in this set.
Stitch markers make an excellent gift for a knitter friend or family member. 

Sock size fits up to a 3.75 mm/US9 needle
Worsted size fits up to a 5.5 mm/US4 needle

The set ordered may not be exactly as shown, colours will vary.

name: Organic & Fair Trade Spinning Cotton - Natural
description:
Difficulty: Advanced

'Natural' is lusciously soft, and lofty. This spinning fibre is both Organic and Fair Trade, it comes from Peru. Organic cotton is gorgeous to spin with, just make sure you have your wheel set up to spin at a fairly fast pace, and use a long-draw method (I use assisted long-draw). I have been spinning almost exclusively with organic cotton for the past few years, except for the occasional dip into bamboo, soysilk, ingeo, linen etc., and I love it more and more. This may be too challenging to a new spinner, in which case you may want to try some of the other fibres available here. but don't worry, cotton is not as hard to spin as you might think, just take your time, and enjoy.

After spinning cotton, you can boil it in plain, untreated water to set the twist.

name: Organic & Fair Trade Spinning Cotton - Sage
description:
Difficulty: Advanced

'Sage' is lusciously soft, and lofty. This spinning fibre is both Organic and Fair Trade, it comes from Peru. Organic cotton is gorgeous to spin with, just make sure you have your wheel set up to spin at a fairly fast pace, and use a long-draw method (I use assisted long-draw). I have been spinning almost exclusively with organic cotton for the past few years, except for the occasional dip into bamboo, soysilk, ingeo, linen etc., and I love it more and more. This may be too challenging to a new spinner, in which case you may want to try some of the other fibres available here. but don't worry, cotton is not as hard to spin as you might think, just take your time, and enjoy.

After spinning cotton, you can boil it in plain, untreated water to set the twist. With naturally pigmented cottons like this one, the colour will slightly deepen the longer you boil it. (5 minutes to 2 hours). The colour also gently 'cures' over time and sets in to an even deeper, richer tone.
